entry.title: Combined summary - DRAFT: interactive tx construction protocol
entry.summary: The Lightning-dev mailing list has been discussing proposals to address issues related to the Lightning Network, including simplifying the channel funding process and implementing anti-fee sniping and masking. One proposal suggests adding a second commitment requirement called PoDLE to limit the validity of a commitment only between an initiator and a single peer. The thread also discusses improvements to protocol messages used in transactions, such as adding a serial ID to inputs and outputs and nLocktime.Another topic of discussion is the use of PoDLEs in lightning transactions, where nodes must include an 'H2' field in the initiating message. Additionally, the email thread proposes various changes, such as sharing the PoDLE format with JoinMarket and mandating its retention for at least a year or a month or two weeks to slow down probe attempts.The discussion also covers topics related to JoinMarket, a bitcoin mixing service that uses the PoDLE proof of discrete logarithm equality to prove that the prover knows the private key corresponding to a given public key.Furthermore, the email thread discusses proposed improvements to protocol messages used in transactions, such as adding a serial ID to inputs and outputs. The removal of signal_rbf makes everything RBF eligible, simplifying the verification process during an RBF round. In multiparty constructions, initiators must flip the bottom bit of any received inputs before relaying them to a peer.The context also discusses the use of block headers to avoid block height disagreements instead of setting block height to -6. The benefits of using PoDLE to prove control over a UTXO are highlighted. Finally, the email exchange includes a question about whether PSBT would be a good solution for transaction collaboration between two peers.The email exchange between Max and Antoine focuses on the integration of nLockTime into C-lightning as part of the Lightning Network protocol. Lisa Neigut shares feedback on the dual-funding proposal, suggesting breaking it into smaller, more manageable chunks. The protocol involves several message types, including tx_add_input, tx_add_output, tx_remove_input, tx_remove_output, tx_complete, and tx_sigs, which are used to initiate transactions of various types (open, close, or splice) with different data fields.Overall, the email exchange provides detailed information about the proposed changes to the Lightning Network protocol and the challenges being faced in its implementation. The use of technical terms and terminology is consistent throughout the exchange, and the information is presented clearly. The different cases discussed in the email exchange, including Simple Open, Splice, and Close, are explained in detail, along with the messages that need to be exchanged between peers.The Lightning-dev mailing list has proposed a new collaborative RBF (Replace-By-Fee) fee bumping option for Lightning Network transactions. According to the proposal, each "fee_step" should add 1/4 to the initial transaction feerate. The proposal aims to make it easier for users to change fees on their transactions while ensuring that they meet certain minimum requirements. Additionally, it should include at least one identical, replaceable input as the original transaction. The proposal has been published on PR #524 and includes a link to the relevant section of the Bitcoin source code where the implementation can be found.
